question: Which weather condition is most commonly associated with warm fronts?

content.source_1: A warm front is the boundary where advancing warm air glides up and over a retreating cooler air mass; the ascent cools the warm air and promotes condensation.
content.source_2: As air cools to its dew point and condenses, stratiform clouds (altostratus to nimbostratus) commonly develop ahead of a warm front and, with sufficient depth and moisture, produce steady, widespread precipitation.
content.source_3: Widespread stratiform precipitation and nimbostratus create overcast skies and rainy weather.
content.source_4: Maritime-tropical warm air masses that feed warm fronts typically originate beneath subtropical high-pressure systems, where subsidence favors generally clear, non-precipitating conditions within the air mass.
content.source_5: Subsiding air in high-pressure systems suppresses cloud growth and precipitation, leading to fair, sunny weather.
content.source_6: Warm fronts transport these warm air masses poleward from their source regions into midlatitudes, carrying the air-mass characteristics into new areas.
